title: 104_hr1497
content: The Act titled "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" revises the limitation on deduction of policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. The amendment states that the deduction for any taxable year shall not exceed 90% of policyholder dividends paid or accrued, or 30% of life insurance. The amendment limits the deduction for policyholder dividends paid by mutual life insurance companies to 90% of dividends or 30% of life insurance company taxable income, with a minimum limitation of $35,000,000 per year. The amendment limits the deduction for policyholder dividends paid by mutual life insurance companies to 90% of dividends or 30% of taxable income, with a minimum limitation of $35,000,000 per year. Stock life insurance companies are treated as mutual if they meet certain ownership criteria. The amendment repeals Section 809 of the Code and amends Section 807(a)(2)(B) to adjust the calculation of the policyholders' share of tax-exempt interest. The Code is being amended to adjust the calculation of policyholders' share of tax-exempt interest in various sections. The Code is being amended to adjust the calculation of policyholders' share of tax-exempt interest in various sections. Subsection (c) of sections 817 and 842 are amended by removing certain paragraphs. The amendments will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1994, with an exception for section 809(f) of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments in this section do not impact section 809(f) of the Internal Revenue Code for taxable years before January 1, 1995. Additionally, for life insurance companies under section 808(b)(2), capital losses after December 31, 1994, cannot be carried back to years before January 1, 1995. Small life insurance companies are exempt from capitalizing certain policy acquisition expenses under Section 848 of the Internal Revenue Code. This exemption applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1994. Additionally, there is a sense of Congress regarding the use of increased revenues. The Congress intends for any additional revenue generated by the amendments to be allocated towards deficit reduction, tax incentives for small life insurance companies, and programs benefiting children's nutrition, education, housing, and family support.
